{@--1@} <ab>N.</ab> of certain mystical writings
attached to the Brāhmaṇas, the
chief aim of which is to ascertain
the secret meaning of the Vedas;
<ls>Bv. 2. 40</ls>; <ls>Māl. 1. 7</ls>; other 
etymologies also are given to explain the
name:--(1) {#upanIya tamAtmAnaM brahmApAstadvayaM#}
{#yataH . nihaMtyavidyAM tajjaM ca tasmAdupanizadBavet ..#}
or (2) {#nihatyAnarTamUlaM svAvidyAM pratyaktayA paraM .#}
{#nayatyapAstasaMBedamato vopanizadBavet ..#} or (3)  
{#pravfttihetUnniHSezAMstanmUlocCedakatvataH .#} 
{#yatovasAdayedvidyA tasmAdupanizadBavet ..#}. In the  
{#muktakopanizad#} 108 Upaniṣads are 
mentioned, but some more have been 
added to this number. They are said
to have been the source of the
six Darśanas or systems of 
philosophy, particularly of the Vedānta
philosophy. The more important
Upaniṣads are:  
--{#ISakenakaWapraSnamuMqamAMqkyatittiraH . EtareyaM ca CAMdogyaM bfhadAraRyakaM#}
{#taTA ..#}.

{@--2@} ({%a%}) An esoteric or secret
doctrine, mystical meaning, words
of mystery. ({%b%}) Mystical 
knowledge or instruction; {#maMtrapArAyaRa°#}  
<ls>U. 6</ls>; <ls>Mv. 2. 2.</ls>

{@--3@} True 
knowledge regarding the Supreme Spirit.
